==Fan Behavior==
==Fan Behavior==
{{Unreferencedsect}}
{{Unreferencedsect}}
â
Eagles fans' devotion to the Eagles is reflected by team ticket sales: games are invariably sold-out, and there is a 60,000-member waiting list for season tickets. In June 2006, tickets for home games were sold out just ten minutes after opening phone and internet lines.
+
Eagles fans' devotion to the Eagles is reflected by team ticket sales: games are invariably sold-out, and there is a 60,000-member waiting list for season tickets.<ref>{{cite web
  +
| url = http://www.philadelphiaeagles.com/team/frontofficebio.jsp?id=658
  +
| title = Front Office Bio - Joe Banner

| publisher = PhiladelphiaEagles.com
  +
| accessdate = 2006-06-22
  +
}}</ref> In June 2006, tickets for home games were sold out in a matter of minutes after opening phone and internet lines.<ref name=berman>{{cite web
  +
| last = Berman
  +
| first = Zack
  +
| date = [[2006-06-14]]
  +
| url = http://www.philadelphiaeagles.com/homeNewsDetail.jsp?id=50198

  +

  +

  +
}}</ref> Despite finishing with a 6-10 record in the 2005-2006 season, the Eagles ranked second in the NFL in merchandise sales the following year.<ref name=berman />
Poor judgment and alcohol have occasionally led some Eagles fans to transgress the boundaries of civilized behavior. Such behavior is familiar to many who have attended professional sporting events virtually anywhere in the world, but Eagles fans have had the misfortune to misbehave in numerous high profile moments, many on national television. As such, Eagles fans have a reputation in many quarters as being unduly rowdy, or even dangerous.
Poor judgment and alcohol have occasionally led some Eagles fans to transgress the boundaries of civilized behavior. Such behavior is familiar to many who have attended professional sporting events virtually anywhere in the world, but Eagles fans have had the misfortune to misbehave in numerous high profile moments, many on national television. As such, Eagles fans have a reputation in many quarters as being unduly rowdy, or even dangerous.
Line 148: Line 148:
}}</ref>
}}</ref>
â
Acts of violence by Eagles fans against fans of visiting teams, combined with ongoing difficulties relating to public drunkenness, prompted Philadelphia municipal judge [[Seamus McCaffrey]] and the [[Philadelphia Police Department]] to establish a small, in-stadium courtroom at the Vet in 1997. Additionally, plainclothes officers, dressed in the colors of the visiting team, dispatched to sit in sections known as being dangerous to opposing fans, most such sections being located in the Vet's notorious "[[700 Level]]" at the top of the stadium. The success of the program was widely noted and has continued to the present day (Lincoln Financial Field includes a built-in prison facility and courtroom for such purposes). Eagle fans caught by such sting operations are arrested, charged and taken to the courtroom, where McCaffrey usually sits in judgment.
+
Acts of violence by Eagles fans against fans of visiting teams, combined with ongoing difficulties relating to public drunkenness, prompted Philadelphia municipal judge [[Seamus McCaffrey]] and the [[Philadelphia Police Department]] to establish a small, in-stadium courtroom at the Vet in 1997. Additionally, plainclothes officers, dressed in the colors of the visiting team, dispatched to sit in sections known as being dangerous to opposing fans, most such sections being located in the Vet's notorious "[[700 Level]]" at the top of the stadium. The success of the program was widely noted and has continued to the present day (Lincoln Financial Field includes a built-in prison facility and courtroom for such purposes). Eagle fans caught by such sting operations are arrested, charged and taken to the courtroom, where McCaffrey usually sits in judgment.
